Families who wish to do in-person learning, but do not wish to use district-provided bus transportation through Winter Break will also have to complete the survey.

Families who plan to return to in-person learning and use district-provided bus transportation this fall DO NOT need to complete the survey.

The deadline to opt out of in-person learning and district provided bus transportation is Friday, July 24, 2020.

With support from the Barrington 220 Educational Foundation, Barrington Youth and Family Services is hosting a virtual workshop and discussion series for middle and high school students called "Surviving and Thriving in Uncertain Times". Each Monday at noon throughout the summer BYFS staff lead a recorded workshop on a different topic with associated exercises. It is then followed by a 30 minute optional discussion session which is not recorded.

On Monday, June 22, the topic is "Coping with Change". Please encourage your middle and high school students to join the zoom discussion to hear more about strategies and skills useful now and in the future. These sessions are stand alone, so it is okay to jump in now if your student has not yet participated!

We heard you. We lowered the referendum's cost by nearly $40 million. Taxes are going down.

With our previous bond debt being paid off, we have a unique opportunity to fund important investments in our schools, while LOWERING property taxes.

The average homeowner ($500,000 home) in the district currently pays approximately $602/year for referendum debt from the previous capital campaign in the late 1990s. As that debt rolls off in 2020 and 2021, property taxes will go down. The cost of the current referendum is approximately $527 per year, which means that if the public approves the March 17 referendum, their property taxes will DECREASE an average of $75/year.

Proud to announce Barrington 220 has earned a spot on the College Board's Advanced Placement Honor Roll for the 5th time! One of only 250 school districts across the US and Canada! Barrington High School offers 35 AP courses.

“This honor is a recognition of efforts made by our teachers and community to provide a rigorous and high quality education to all Barrington 220 students,” said BHS Principal Steve McWilliams. “Our focus is to prepare all students to successfully transition from Barrington 220 to their next phase of life; whether that next step is college or a career path. Successful completion of an AP course is one of many indicators of college and career readiness.”
